title: 105_s2207
content:
The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" aims to empower the Attorney General to prevent mergers and acquisitions that could restrict competition in the telecommunications industry. It amends the Clayton Act to address restraints of trade specifically related to telecommunications. The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" defines a large local telephone company as one serving more than 5% of telephone access lines in the US. It prohibits mergers or acquisitions of such companies unless they promote competition and meet certain requirements set by the Attorney General and the Federal Communications Commission. The Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998 defines a large local telephone company as serving over 5% of telephone access lines in the US. It prohibits mergers or acquisitions unless they promote competition and meet requirements set by the Attorney General and the Federal Communications Commission, including reporting to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees within 10 days of a finding. Application for mergers must be filed with both the Attorney General and FCC simultaneously. The Communications Commission must issue a decision on the application within the specified time frame. The district courts have jurisdiction to prevent mergers inconsistent with specified findings. The Attorney General can take legal action in district courts if a merger does not meet conditions or if the FCC finds issues with the parties involved. The Communications Commission must issue a decision on mergers within a specified time frame. District courts have jurisdiction to prevent mergers that do not meet requirements. The Attorney General can take legal action if a merger is found to be inconsistent with specified findings. SEC. 4. PRESERVATION OF EXISTING AUTHORITIES.

This Act does not affect antitrust laws or the FCC's authority under the Communications Act of 1934 regarding mergers of large incumbent local exchange carriers.

SEC. 5. APPLICABILITY.

This Act applies to mergers or acquisitions of controlling interests in large local telephone companies after its enactment.
